questions.text: A 25-year-old female with pog 32 weeks comes to AIIMS ANC OPD for a routine checkup. On performing the Leopold maneuver following findings were noted- First: the fundus was occupied by a small, round hard structure. Second: hard broad back to be on one side of the abdomen and knobby on the other side. Third: soft irregular mass movable above the pelvic inlet. What should be the presentation and denominator of the fetus?
questions.correct_answer: C. Breech presentation and sacrum denominator
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breech presentation and sacrum denominator In the given question, the interpretation of the Leopold maneuver suggests that the head occupies the fundus (small, round hard structure.) And soft regular movable mass above the pelvic inlet denotes the breech hence, the fetus has breech presentation and the denominator in breech presentation is the sacrum .

questions.text: A 26-Year-old female was admitted in advance labour at 40 weeks. On PV examination- membranes were ruptured, and the buttocks and groin were felt but not the feet of the baby. The obstetrician then performed the pinard maneuver for breech extraction. Which of the following images depicts the following maneuver ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

d Image d depicts the Pinard maneuver in which the middle and the index fingers are carried up to the popliteal Fossa . It is then pressed and abducted so that the fetal leg is flexed . The fetal foot is then grasped at the ankle and breech extraction is accomplished.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: depicts the burnt marshall maneuver for the aftercoming head of the fetus. Option B: shows Groin traction Option C: shows Mauriceau Smellie veit technique for delivery of aftercoming head in the breech.

questions.text: A 35-Year-old female with G2P0A1L0 came to attend an ANC clinic at 37 weeks of POG. The USG report confirms the fetus to be in breech presentation. The estimated fetal weight is 4kg. Also, a third-trimester scan shows a low-lying placenta. The patient is concerned regarding her delivery and wants the safe delivery of the child. The pelvis is adequate. What is the best management option?

options.label: A
options.text: Awaits spontaneous onset of labour and NVD

options.label: B
options.text: Perform elective c – section at 39 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: If labour becomes prolonged, then perform a C-section

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform elective c – section at 39 weeks
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perform elective c – section at 39 weeks In the given question, the weight of the baby is 4kg(> 3.5 kg) and USG shows low lying placenta which may not be favourable for NVD even after the external cephalic version (option d) . Hence in these situations, we should do elective C Section at >= 38 weeks . So option B is the right answer.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. We should not wait for spontaneous labour as it is not favourable for this patient. Option: C. Prolonged labour will impose risk on both fetus and the mother , hence we should avoid this situation and do an elective c-section. Option: D. Perform external cephalic version is not recommended in a breech baby with low lying placenta.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 female with previous H/O LSCS presents at 36 weeks of gestation with breech presentation. Next step in management:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ECV at 37 weeks In the given case, a female with breech presentation presents at 36 weeks . At this stage, the external cephalic version is the most appropriate management. The history of LSCS is not a contraindication of ECV.

questions.text: Among the following types of breech, which are indications of mandatory cesarean section? A. Complete breech B. Incomplete breech C. Stargazing breech Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B, C Types of breech along with their management: Flexed/ Complete Vaginal delivery can be tried Extended/Frank breech Best for vaginal delivery Footling A cesarean section is a must Stargazer A cesarean section is a must Therefore statements B and C are correct.

questions.text: The incidence of cord prolapse is least in
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Frank breech Cord Prolapse : Cord prolapse is the condition where the umbilical cord lies below the presenting part after the rupture of membranes. The least risk of cord prolapse is seen in frank breech.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The highest risk of cord prolapse is seen in footling breech Option: C. Overall, the highest risk of cord prolapse in a transverse lie Option: D. Brow presentation is not associated with incidence of cord prolapse B

questions.text: You are attending obstetrics opd along with your consultant. She has called four patients in whom breech presentation was confirmed clinically as well as by ultrasonography to check whether an external cephalic version can be done or not. Which of the following patients is the most suitable candidate for ECV?

options.label: A
options.text: 38-week primigravida with grade iii placenta previa

options.label: B
options.text: 37-week g2p1 female with prior c- section 15 months back

options.label: C
options.text: 37-week primigravida with intact membranes, adequate liquor and complete breech

options.label: D
options.text: 37 week +2 day female with membrane intact, adequate liquor and twin gestation

questions.correct_answer: C. 37-week primigravida with intact membranes, adequate liquor and complete breech
questions.explanation:
Solution:

37-week primigravida with intact membranes, adequate liquor and complete breech External cephalic version is an OPD procedure which is attempted at >= 37 weeks of gestation with conditions like an intact membrane , adequate liquor , vaginal delivery should not be a contraindication, and facility of emergency C-section should be available. Absolute Contraindications for ECV: Placenta previa Multiple pregnancies H/O antepartum haemorrhage IUGR Severe preeclampsia and hypertension ee.com Rupture of membranes ECV is performed with caution and without force in patients with lower uterine scars. It is not contraindicated.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- In Option A , the female is a case of placenta previa , hence it is not a suitable candidate. In Option D , the female presents with twin gestation, hence not a suitable candidate as well. Among Option B & C , the female in option C is a more suitable candidate as she has intact membranes and adequate liquor .
